Name: Impermanent Loss 1 - What You Must Know First
Post Body:
INTRODUCTION â€” The Tension Beneath the Surface

The Academy had settled into its evening silence.
Most screens were dark, corridors empty, the hum of servers soft as breath.
But in the observatory wing â€” where concepts were usually tested before they were taught â€” two desks still glowed.

One belonged to Tao.
Papers spread across the surface: diagrams of markets, notes from field research, half-scribbled translations meant for students across distant time zones. He was a tutor by nature â€” calm, thoughtful, always trying to make ideas accessible. But tonight, he looked unsettled, as if the knowledge in front of him kept slipping sideways.

Across from him sat Ava.
Quiet. Precise. A calm presence in the glass-blue light. She had the kind of mind that could walk inside a structure â€” any structure â€” and trace its skeleton with a single glance. Tao often said that speaking with her felt like being shown a map you didnâ€™t know youâ€™d been walking on.

Tonight, the map was giving him trouble.

The screen between them glowed with charts from a liquidity pool â€” green waves rising, red waves falling, numbers shifting just fast enough to be unnerving.

Tao exhaled slowly.

â€œI keep seeing this term everywhere,â€ he said. â€œImpermanent loss. LPs. Pools. Divergence. Symmetry. Everyone throws the words around like theyâ€™re obvious. But when I try to explain it to students â€” or even to myself â€” something doesnâ€™t line up. I feel like Iâ€™m missing the real shape of it.â€

Ava closed the notebook in front of her.

â€œThatâ€™s because most people meet impermanent loss after it has already hurt them,â€ she said. â€œThey hear about high yield, easy rewards, passive income â€” and they step into a structure they donâ€™t actually understand. Only later do they ask why their balance shrank even when the market moved in their favor.â€

Tao frowned.
â€œSo itâ€™s not just a risk term. Itâ€™s a misunderstanding with consequences.â€

â€œExactly.â€ Avaâ€™s voice was steady. â€œImpermanent loss isnâ€™t a punishment. Itâ€™s a structural effect. A pool balancing itself against a market that refuses to stay still. If you donâ€™t understand that, the numbers feel hostile. Confusing. Unfair. But once you understand the geometry of it â€” the way a pool holds its shape â€” the confusion dissolves. And the user sees why liquidity can be both a gift and a cost.â€

Tao leaned back, absorbing her words.
â€œSo the real danger isnâ€™t the loss itselfâ€¦ itâ€™s stepping in blind.â€

Ava nodded.

â€œAnd the real benefit,â€ she added, â€œis that once someone understands it, liquidity stops feeling like a trap. It becomes a predictable structure â€” one you can engage with on purpose, not by accident.â€

Tao lifted one of his pages, covered in crossed-out explanations.
â€œI tried to teach this earlier today. But I realized I didnâ€™t understand it deeply enough to guide anyone. Maybe we should start from the beginning â€” not a lecture, just a conversation. You lead. I follow. We sharpen the edges together.â€

Avaâ€™s expression softened â€” a faint, knowing smile.

â€œA dialogue, then,â€ she said. â€œYour questions. My structure. We begin with nothing assumed. Not what a pool is, not what a token pair means, not why divergence creates tension inside the system. Step by step. Until the fog lifts.â€

Tao glanced once more at the shifting chart on the screen â€” two tokens locked in a dance he didnâ€™t yet understand.

â€œGood,â€ he said quietly. â€œBecause if I feel this lost, our learners feel twice as lost. And Iâ€™d rather open the door for them than let them walk into a system that punishes confusion.â€

Ava folded her hands.

â€œThen letâ€™s open the door,â€ she said. â€œWe start with the place where impermanent loss is born â€” the liquidity pool itself.â€â€

â€Chapter 1 â€” The Pool

The chart on the screen shifted again â€” two lines, two tokens, drifting slightly apart.
Tao traced the movement with his eyes, the way one curve rose while the other dipped.
â€œI understand price,â€ he murmured. â€œBut why does the pool react like this? It looksâ€¦ alive.â€

Ava leaned forward, her elbows resting on the desk, her voice low enough to match the roomâ€™s hush.

â€œThatâ€™s because a liquidity pool isnâ€™t a vault,â€ she said. â€œItâ€™s not a bag of tokens waiting on a shelf. Itâ€™s a balancing mechanism. A structure that holds two assets in a precise relationship â€” a relationship that must remain intact, no matter what the market outside decides to do.â€

Tao blinked.
â€œSo the pool is constantly adjusting itself?â€

â€œYes,â€ Ava replied. â€œTwo tokens, locked together. You deposit them in equal value â€” a pairing, a symmetry. And the moment you do, the pool begins its work: it must preserve that symmetry, even if the world outside refuses to cooperate.â€

Tao studied the chart again.
The lines didnâ€™t look like lines anymore. They looked like tension held in motion.

â€œI always thought liquidity meant making trades easier,â€ he said. â€œI never thought of it asâ€¦ a structure under pressure.â€

â€œThatâ€™s the part most people overlook,â€ Ava said. â€œLiquidity pools make markets smoother, faster, more efficient. They allow users to trade without waiting for someone else to take the other side. But convenience has a cost. The pool provides liquidity by bending â€” by rearranging itself so every trade keeps the ratio intact.â€

Taoâ€™s brows knit.
â€œSo when someone buys one token from the poolâ€¦ the pool must give it up and take more of the other one to stay balanced?â€

â€œExactly,â€ Ava said. â€œItâ€™s mechanical. If people buy Token A, the pool ends up with less A and more B. If they sell A, the pool ends up with more A and less B. Always shifting, always holding the 50/50 value split. The pool never argues. It just reshapes itself.â€

Tao tapped a finger against the desk, absorbing the idea.
â€œSo every trade pushes the pool slightly off-center, and the pool pulls itself back into symmetry.â€

Ava nodded.
â€œThatâ€™s the heart of it. And that balancing act â€” that relentless reshaping â€” is where the roots of impermanent loss begin. Not in loss. In symmetry.â€

Tao let that word hang between them.

Symmetry.
Order inside motion.
A structure trying to stay whole while the world around it moves.

â€œThat means,â€ Tao said slowly, â€œthat liquidity providers donâ€™t just deposit tokens. They enter into a relationship with a system that reacts to the market in real time.â€

â€œYes,â€ Ava said softly. â€œAnd that relationship is often misunderstood. People see the yield. They see rewards. They donâ€™t see the poolâ€™s shape tightening and loosening around their position. They donâ€™t see how divergence on the outside forces redistribution on the inside.â€

Tao felt a familiar shift â€” the moment when a concept begins to reveal its deeper architecture.

â€œSo the real question isnâ€™t why impermanent loss happens,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s why the pool must hold its shape in the first place.â€

Avaâ€™s eyes met his.

â€œPrecisely. And once you understand why symmetry must be preserved, impermanent loss stops feeling like a mystery. It becomes a predictable outcome of a system doing exactly what it was designed to do.â€

Tao nodded, his earlier uncertainty dissolving into curiosity.

â€œThen letâ€™s follow the shape,â€ he said. â€œIf the poolâ€™s symmetry is the root, I want to understand the rule it follows â€” the geometry underneath.â€

Ava reached for her notebook again, the faint scratch of the pen echoing in the quiet room.

â€œThen we move to the equation that governs every pool,â€ she said. â€œThe rule that keeps the structure alive.â€

She looked up.

â€œNext chapter: The Constant Product.â€

Chapter 2 â€” The Constant Product

The room felt even quieter now â€” as if the Academy itself leaned in, waiting for the next piece to fall into place.

Ava flipped open her notebook, revealing a single line written at the top of the page:

x Â· y = k

Tao stared at it.
Two variables. One constant.
Deceptively simple.

â€œThis,â€ Ava said softly, â€œis the rule every liquidity pool lives by. A single equation that decides how much of each token the pool must hold at any moment. The poolâ€™s symmetry isnâ€™t a suggestion â€” itâ€™s a law. And this law is its heartbeat.â€

Tao leaned closer, tracing the symbol with his eyes.
â€œSo x and yâ€¦ the amounts of the two tokens?â€

â€œYes,â€ Ava replied. â€œToken A and Token B. Their quantities shift constantly as people trade against the pool. But no matter how violently the market moves outside, the product of those two amounts must stay equal to one thing â€” k, the constant.â€

Tao exhaled.

â€œSo the pool has one instruction:
â€˜Whatever happens, keep x times y equal to k.â€™â€

Ava nodded.
â€œAnd that instruction forces the pool to bend. If one token is taken out, the other must increase in quantity to keep the equation balanced. If one side rises in market price, the pool must hold less of it. If one side falls, the pool must accumulate more.â€

Taoâ€™s expression shifted â€” curiosity turning into recognition.

â€œThat means the pool never holds what the market holds. It always holds what the equation demands.â€

â€œExactly,â€ Ava said. â€œMost newcomers think liquidity providers earn yield while holding the same tokens they deposited. But thatâ€™s not true. The moment you enter the pool, you surrender your fixed position. The system begins moving your tokens for you, redistributing them to satisfy the constant product.â€
